B000002UA2|4.0|Obscured by Clouds, the 1972 soundtrack to the obscure French film (set in Papua New Guinea) La Valle composed and performed by a little-known band called Pink Floyd. Should be fun. <br /> <br />The opening cut is the album's title track, an instrumental entitled \\"Obscured by Clouds\\" (yes, title track, see?) which is pleasant, very much Pink Floyd-sounding, but at the same time an obvious departure from the stylings of 1971's Meddle - the immediate predecessor to Obscured by Clouds - that manages to suggest both Meddle and 1973's The Dark Side of Moon - the immediate successor to Obscured by Clouds - without being either. It defines its own sound and informs the listener that this album is not just a watered-down version of another classic Gilmour/Waters Floyd album. It's quite nice, really. <br /> <br />It was probably a mistake to put one instrumental right after another, but it's a soundtrack. What can you expect, really? The second track is called \\"When You're In\\" and really doesn't stand out a whole lot to me. It's pleasant, drum-and-guitar-driven mood music, but it doesn't have the interest of \\"Obscured by Clouds\\" and is no match for the complexities of \\"Echoes\\", \\"Shine On You Crazy Diamond\\", or \\"On the Run\\" and is fairly repetative. Very repetative, actually. <br /> <br />\\"Burning Bridges\\" is not instrumental, but has a pastoral, meandering tone and rather subdued vocals that do progress in volume and clarity further into the song. It has interesting lyrics, but definitely isn't a favorite of mine or an album standout track. It's all right. Notably, it still manages to rise above most else that Pink Floyd had done by 1972 since 1967's \\"Lucifer Sam\\" off of the Syd Barrett-directed The Piper at the Gates of Dawn. <br /> <br />The next song is an unexpected blues-rocker called, improbably, \\"The Gold It's In The...\\" Now, it's hard to be truly sure what the gold is in, but it's a rocking good song. Unlike with Meddle's eerie, experimentally tropical \\"San Tropez\\", \\"The Gold It's In The...\\" does not sound disturbing as a result of it being a cross-genre Floyd performance. You know, as a matter of fact, if the band had played around with more bluesy arrangements after running out of atmospheric soundscapes and sonic textures to explore in their later days, both with Roger Waters and after his departure, their post-The Wall material might have been a little more classic and well-liked. This song ends too soon, unfortunately. It feels oddly incomplete. <br /> <br />If you thought \\"The Gold It's In The...\\" was a strange title for a song, \\"Wot's...Uh The Deal\\" beats it out there. It's a bit dreamier and floatier than The Dark Side of the Moon and the other classic album pieces, and the lyrics aren't quite as thoughtful, but it's still a nice song. <br /> <br />\\"Mudmen\\" starts off as another unassuming instrumental before opening up into a familiar-sounding musical assault from Rick Wright aboard his toy, the distortedish organ memorable from The Dark Side of the Moon's \\"Any Colour You Like\\". It was about at this point that The Wall yielded to Obscured by Clouds on my ranking of favorite Pink Floyd albums, giving it the number four slot behind, in ascending order, Animals, Wish You Were Here, and The Dark Side of the Moon. Interesting, yes? <br /> <br />And then the next song, \\"Childhood's End\\", one I'm familiar with and have heard a few times before, is just plain incredible. The lyrics are intelligent and driving, the vocals are biting and have a brilliant edge to them, the musicianship is staggering as always, and the composition is very effective indeed. Definitely my favorite cut off this album and among my top ten favorite Pink Floyd songs, which I won't even try to rank. <br /> <br />\\"Free Four\\" is all right, kind of strange for me. It's a jaunty pop tune that begins to slide into the \\"San Tropez\\" rut of just being too \\"out there\\" by not being \\"out there\\" enough. It may not make any sense, but it's Pink Floyd, and really itdoes. Despite the upbeat, pop sort of sound, there's those long, penetrating notes that hit regularly to remind you that this really is still Pink Floyd. Oh, and the lyrics are about death. <br /> <br />The next song is a ballad piece called \\"Stay\\", which might be pretty moving in the context of the film. I should try to hunt down an English-subtitled version someday. As part of Obscured by Clouds, though, \\"Stay\\" isn't immediately affecting or catching. It's rather like \\"Burning Bridges\\" in that regard. <br /> <br />\\"Absolutely Curtains\\" closes the album, an instrumental with a very typically Roger Waters title. Rick Wright again demonstrates his invaluable keyboard skills, which might be just what put this album over The Wall (which lacks Wright completely). It ends with a Papuan tribal chant, probably from the movie itself, thus echoing \\"Fearless\\" from Meddle. And from there, it's just moving on into The Dark Side of the Moon and beyond. <br /> <br />Obscured by Clouds is a soundtrack, so the segue of one track into the next familiar to those listeners of classic Pink Floyd is completely absent. This is sad. Also sad is how some of the songs just seem to be abbreviated. The album also occasionally just floats, more at the beginning and end than in the middle (which is easily the strongest part of the album, the meat to the beginning and end's bread), but no more - and in fact, less - than Meddle with its peaceful, unassuming arrangements and melodies. <br /> <br />I also like it better than The Wall, probably because of the keyboard work of Rick Wright and the vocals of David Gilmour. Funny, eh?
